According to the document, what core value underpins Axess's operations, technically and commercially? What is at its core operationally, technically, and commercially, according to the document?
Axess was formed with clear principles that put Integrity at its core operationally, technically, and commercially.
What types of hardware does Axess offer for the insertion and retrieval of monitoring, injection, and sampling devices?

Axess offers hardware for monitoring, injection, and sampling devices, including Mechanical & Hydraulic High-Pressure Access systems, Low Pressure Access Systems, Corrosion Coupons, Erosion/Sand Detection Probes, Retrieval Tools and Service Valves.
What factors can influence the occurrence and development rate of corrosion and erosion, as well as the rate at which chemicals mix and disperse within a process?
Pipe geometry, flow conditions, and process fluid can influence corrosion and erosion development, as well as chemical mixing and dispersion rates.
Where can corrosion monitoring points be located to effectively monitor corrosion and chemical effectiveness?
Corrosion monitoring points can be located downstream of process changes and at the end of the line to ensure chemical effectiveness.
Where are the areas at high risk for erosion in a piping system, according to the document?
Erosion risk is higher downstream of chokes, at locations with rapid changes in direction (small radius bends, T-sections), and where sand is present.
To which industry standards is Axess's hardware manufactured?
Axess's hardware is manufactured to meet industry standards such as NACE MR0175, ASME B31.3, EN10204-3.1, and ISO:9001:2015.

Axess sources materials from N. America and W. Europe.

Axess offers Mechanical & Hydraulic High-Pressure Access systems, Low Pressure Access Systems, Corrosion Coupons, Erosion/Sand Detection Probes, Retrieval Tools and Service Valves.
According to the document, where is erosion a risk due to rapid changes in direction?
Erosion is a risk at locations with rapid changes in direction such as small radius bends, and T-sections.
According to the document, where can corrosion monitoring points be located in relation to process changes and the end of the line?
Corrosion monitoring points can be located downstream of any process change including branch connections where additional process streams are introduced, and at the end of the line.

Axess designs and manufactures systems based on the client's application.

According to the document, what factors influence the occurrence and development rate of corrosion and erosion within a facility?

Pipe geometry, flow conditions and process fluid can all influence the occurrence and the development rate of corrosion and erosion within a facility as well as effecting the rate at which chemicals mix and disperse within the process.
According to the document, where does Axess source the materials for their monitoring, injection, and sampling devices?
Axess sources materials from N. America and W. Europe.
What does Axess offer for non-intrusive corrosion and erosion monitoring of process pipework and vessels, and what temperature range can the ultrasonic transducers withstand?

Non-intrusive wall thickness solutions provide in-service corrosion and erosion monitoring using ultrasonic transducers, up to 550℃ permanently mounted to process pipework, vessels and other structures coupled with a range of instrumentation options from spot reading, through to online, real-time wireless monitoring using industry standards WirelessHART/ISA100 protocols, or cellular networks.
What factor determines the rate of chemical injection, measured in gallons per day, in an Axess corrosion control system?
The rate of chemical injection (gallons/day) is determined by the min/max capacity of the injection pump.
When injecting chemicals in a piping system where there is a change of material, how far upstream should the injection point ideally be located, according to Axess Corrosion?
The injection point should ideally be located a minimum of 10 x pipe ID upstream of the change in material.
According to Axess Corrosion, what are the important factors to consider when selecting a chemical injection point?
Chemical density and viscosity, process pipe/vessel size, velocity, pressure, temperature, and fluid composition.
What are the differences between using an atomiser and an open quill for chemical injection, and what is the preferred method for pulse injection according to Axess Corrosion?

Using an atomiser in a gas system can help with fine volume control by adjusting the injection differential pressure and maintaining a constant application of the chemical. Chemicals injected using an open quill are applied in a pulse method with the frequency determined by the stroke rate of the chemical injection pump. The preferred method is a low stroke volume with a high stroke frequency to minimise the time between each pulse injection of chemical.
Where should chemical injection points be located relative to the equipment and pipework requiring protection, according to Axess Corrosion guidelines?
Chemical injection points should always be located upstream of the equipment and pipework requiring protection.
When should wake frequency and drag calculations be considered for chemical injection, and what is their purpose according to Axess Corrosion?
For higher velocity processes, wake frequency / drag calculations should be considered to determine maximum length whilst maintaining the integrity of the injection device.
What type of sensors does Axess use for non-intrusive wall thickness monitoring?
Axess offers non-intrusive wall thickness solutions that use ultrasonic transducers permanently mounted to process pipework, vessels, and other structures.
What is the maximum temperature that the ultrasonic transducers used in Axess' non-intrusive wall thickness solutions can withstand?
The ultrasonic transducers can withstand temperatures up to 550℃.
What are the instrumentation options available for Axess' non-intrusive wall thickness monitoring systems?
Instrumentation options range from spot reading to online, real-time wireless monitoring using WirelessHART/ISA100 protocols or cellular networks.
How does using an atomiser for chemical injection help with volume control, and in what type of system is it most appropriate according to Axess Corrosion?
An atomiser can help with fine volume control by adjusting the injection differential pressure and maintaining a constant application of the chemical, particularly in a gas system.
Where is the ideal location for chemical injection, and under what conditions should wake frequency and drag calculations be considered according to Axess Corrosion?

The ideal injection location is normally centre line; however, for higher velocity processes, wake frequency / drag calculations should be considered to determine maximum length whilst maintaining the integrity of the injection device.
According to Axess Corrosion, what do the following acronyms stand for in the context of corrosion and erosion monitoring: AX, CC, ER, LPR, SP, UT, and H?
The acronyms are: AX (Access Systems), CC (Corrosion Coupon), ER (Electrical Resistance), LPR (Linear Polarisation Resistance), SP (Sand Probe), UT (Non Intrusive), and H (Hydrogen Probe).
According to Axess Corrosion, what factors related to the chemical and the process environment are important to consider when selecting a chemical injection point?
Chemical density and viscosity, process pipe/vessel size, velocity, pressure, temperature, and fluid composition.
According to Axess Corrosion, what factor determines the rate of chemical injection in gallons per day?
The rate of chemical injection is determined by the min/max capacity of the injection pump.
What type of transducers are used in Axess' non-intrusive wall thickness solutions, and what is their maximum operating temperature?
Non-intrusive wall thickness solutions utilize ultrasonic transducers capable of withstanding temperatures up to 550℃.
What range of instrumentation options are available for Axess' non-intrusive wall thickness monitoring systems?
The instrumentation options range from spot reading to online, real-time wireless monitoring using industry standards WirelessHART/ISA100 protocols, or cellular networks.
According to Axess Corrosion, what is the preferred method for pulse injection of chemicals, in terms of stroke volume and frequency?
In most cases, the preferred method is to have a low stroke volume with a high stroke frequency to minimize the time between each pulse injection of chemical.
Under what conditions should wake frequency and drag calculations be considered for chemical injection, and what is their purpose according to Axess Corrosion?
For higher velocity processes, wake frequency / drag calculations should be considered to determine maximum length whilst maintaining the integrity of the injection device.
What type of sensor and maximum temperature rating are used in Axess' non-intrusive wall thickness monitoring solutions?
The system uses ultrasonic transducers that can withstand temperatures up to 550℃.
What are the different instrumentation options available for Axess' non-intrusive wall thickness monitoring systems, including the wireless communication protocols used?
The instrumentation options range from spot reading to online, real-time wireless monitoring using industry standards WirelessHART/ISA100 protocols, or cellular networks.
According to Axess Corrosion, what determines the rate of chemical injection in gallons per day?
The rate of chemical injection (gallons/day) is determined by the min/max capacity of the injection pump.
In general process piping applications, what straight length upstream and downstream is recommended to ensure spray dispersion for chemical injection and sampling?
A minimum of 3-5 pipe diameters of straight length upstream and 5-10 pipe diameters of straight length downstream are recommended to ensure spray dispersion in general process piping applications.
What causes an Axess retrieval tool to piston?

Retrieval tools are designed for pressure balance between the tool and the process. Equalization can be achieved through the carrier plug design, but over time the equalization ports can be blocked with scale or solids, especially at bottom of the line orientation. If equalization is not achieved prior to the disengagement of the carrier plug, there is a risk of pistoning.
What are the dangers associated with using non-telescoping retrieval tools?

Non-telescoping retrieval tools have external handles that can violently whip when pressure surges as the plug completely unseats from the fitting without pressure equalization. Recent research suggests this type of retriever has been responsible for an increase in operator injuries over the past 10 years.
What is the advantage of the Axess Janus™ Guard?
The Janus™ Guard can save lives by preventing retrieval tool barrels from pistoning and handles from whipping, thereby removing the 'line of fire'.
What sizes of access fittings is the Axess hot-tapping equipment designed for online installation compatible with?
Axess provides the safest hot-tapping equipment designed for the online installation of both 1" and 2" access fittings.
What does the Axess patented design for 'Plug & Abandon' allow operators to do with redundant welded access fittings?
Axess patented design allows operators to purge the voids within the fittings and seal the cavities with corrosion resistant sealants.
What is the pressure rating of the standard Axess four cell manifold, and what is the maximum pressure rating available for well testing applications?

Axess standard four cell manifold is designed to provide the ability to monitor with multiple sensor types and easily connect to process outlets or sample points. Standard options are rated to 1000psi and manifolds up to 10'000psi are available for well testing applications.
When using mechanical retrieval equipment during Axess training, what pressure can be achieved on the custom flow loop?
When using the mechanical equipment, Janus™ guards will be fitted to the retrievers and we can perform hundreds of retrievals on our custom flow loop at pressure up to 2000psi.
According to Axess, what measurements are included in coupon analysis and reporting?

Weight loss is the central measurement and the two methods of cleaning ensures very little metal loss occurs during that process. An average weight loss during cleaning is factored in to the final weights to improve accuracy of the data. White light and pit depth are measurement options as well as microbial data results from swabs taken immediately after coupon retrieval.
According to Axess, what components are the safest in the business?
Axess retrieval tools, service valves, and fittings.
According to Axess, what are the risks associated with back pressuring during the retrieval process?
The risks stem from equipment availability, calibration, and the practicalities with using the equipment during every retrieval. Accurate pressure verification is critical and not always possible.
What are the key features of Axess hot-tapping equipment and the Janus™ service valve kit?

Axess provides the safest hot-tapping equipment designed for the online installation of both 1" and 2" access fittings. The Janus™ service valve kit provides a genuine double seal of the fitting connection and double isolation of the process.
According to Axess, what calculations are performed to ensure the correct devices are supplied for chemical injection and sampling?
Axess will help you specify the correct nozzle and ensure the devices supplied pass wake frequency / drag force calculations.
What technology is included with all Axess retrieval tools, and what other products incorporate Axess innovations?
All Axess retrieval tools are supplied with Janus™ technology, and innovations extend to Retrokit, Janus™ Service Valves, and Access Fittings.
What type of training programs does Axess provide?
Axess provides the most complete training and certification programs for the safe use of online retrieval tools.
How is pressure equalization achieved in Axess retrieval tools, and what can cause it to fail?
Equalization can be achieved through the carrier plug design, but over time the equalization ports can be blocked with scale or solids, especially at bottom of the line orientation.
What are the features of the Axess standard four cell manifold for sidestream monitoring?

Axess standard four cell manifold is designed to provide the ability to monitor with multiple sensor types and easily connect to process outlets or sample points. The units are customizable and portable. Standard options are rated to 1000psi and manifolds up to 10'000psi are available for well testing applications.
According to Axess, what services are provided to ensure proper chemical injection and sampling?
Axess will help specify the correct nozzle and ensure the devices supplied pass wake frequency / drag force calculations.
How does the Axess Janus™ Guard enhance safety during retrieval tool operations?
The Janus™ Guard prevents retrieval tool barrels from pistoning and handles from whipping, removing the 'line of fire'.
What solutions does Axess provide for data delivery and power in remote monitoring locations?

Axess offers flexible cellular and satellite options, paired with energy harvesting options like solar panels with battery backup, to ensure uninterrupted monitoring in remote locations where power is unavailable.
What is the resolution of the Axess DCU & HHU?
The Axess DCU & HHU has a resolution of 20 bits.
What is the memory capacity (in number of readings) of the Axess DCU & HHU?
The Axess DCU & HHU can store 7,200 readings.
What is the operating temperature range of the Axess DCU & HHU?
The Axess DCU & HHU can operate in temperatures ranging from -20°C to +70℃ (-4°F to +158°F).
What type of power supply does the Axess DCU & HHU use, and what are its specifications?
The Axess DCU & HHU uses a Lithium Battery Pack (7.2V 5Ah) as its power supply.
What IECEx and ATEX certifications does the Axess DCU & HHU have?
The Axess DCU & HHU is certified to IECEx Ex ia IIC T4 Ga/Gb and ATEX Ex II 1/2 G Ex ia IIC T4 Ga/Gb.
What is the Ingress Protection rating of the Axess DCU & HHU?
The Axess DCU & HHU has an ingress protection rating of IP66.
What communication protocol does the Axess DCU & HHU use, and what are its parameters?
The Axess DCU & HHU communicates via RS-232 Serial ASCII Bus 9600, 8, N, 1.
What is the weight of the Axess DCU & HHU?
The Axess DCU & HHU weighs 1.7kg (3.8lb).
What type of probe measurement is supported by the Axess DCU & HHU?
The Axess DCU & HHU can measure Galvanic Potential.
What type of battery and what are the voltage and amperage specifications for the Axess DCU & HHU?
The Axess DCU & HHU uses a Lithium Battery Pack with specifications of 7.2V 5Ah.
What are the IECEx and ATEX certifications for the Axess DCU & HHU?
The Axess DCU & HHU has IECEx certification Ex ia IIC T4 Ga/Gb and ATEX certification Ex II 1/2 G Ex ia IIC T4 Ga/Gb.
What communication protocol and parameters are used by the Axess DCU & HHU?
The Axess DCU & HHU uses RS-232 Serial ASCII Bus with parameters 9600, 8, N, 1 for communication.
What is the weight of the Axess DCU & HHU in kilograms and pounds?
The Axess DCU & HHU weighs 1.7kg (3.8lb).
What types of probes is the Axess DCU (Data Collection Unit) capable of reading?
The Axess DCU is capable of reading all types of electrical resistance (ER), linear polarization resistance (LPR) and galvanic probes.
How many data points can the Axess DCU preserve in its internal memory?
The Axess DCU can preserve up to 7,200 data points in its internal memory.
What are the dimensions of the Axess Data Collection Unit?
The dimensions of the Axess Data Collection Unit are 6.5" x 6.5" x 4.25" (165mm x 165mm x 108mm).
What communication protocol does the Axess DCU use?
The Axess DCU uses a RS-232 Serial ASCII Bus 9600, 8, N, 1 for communication.
Why can the Axess DCU be used with electrical resistance (ER), linear polarization resistance (LPR), and galvanic probes?

The Axess DCU can be used with electrical resistance (ER), linear polarization resistance (LPR), and galvanic probes because it is designed to read metal loss, corrosion rate, and current/potential respectively.
What type of battery powers the Axess DCU, and what are its specifications?
The Axess DCU is powered by a 7.2V 5Ah Lithium Battery Pack.
What is the operating temperature range for the Axess DCU?
The temperature range for the Axess DCU is -20°C to +70℃ (-4°F to +158°F).
What is the part number for the Axess Data Collection Unit?
The part number for the Axess Data Collection Unit is AXDCUHB.
What are the benefits of the GRP enclosure used for the Axess DCU?
The GRP enclosure of the Axess DCU allows for lightweight construction and optional mounting to site structures or Axess low and high pressure access systems.
What is the Ingress Protection rating of the Axess DCU?
The Axess DCU is rated IP66 for Ingress Protection.
What are the two methods for configuring the Axess DCU (Data Collection Unit)?
The Axess DCU can be configured either with the Axess HHU or on the DCU LED panel.
What is the part number for the Axess DCU (Data Collection Unit) Mounting Bracket Kit?
The Axess DCU mounting bracket kit has part number AXDCUBRKT.
What are the specifications for the communication bus used by the Axess DCU (Data Collection Unit)?
The Axess DCU uses a RS-232 Serial ASCII Bus 9600, 8, N, 1 for communication.
What are the IECEx and ATEX certifications for the Axess DCU (Data Collection Unit)?
The Axess DCU has IECEx Ex ia IIC T4 Ga/Gb and ATEX Ex II 1/2 G Ex ia IIC T4 Ga/Gb certifications.
What is the voltage and capacity of the Lithium Battery Pack used in the Axess DCU (Data Collection Unit)?
The Axess DCU uses a 7.2V 5Ah Lithium Battery Pack.
What is the expected battery life of the Axess DCU (Data Collection Unit) when taking readings every 6 hours?
The battery life of the Axess DCU is up to 5 years when taking readings every 6 hours.
What is the benefit of the Axess DCU (Data Collection Unit) being compatible with electrical resistance (ER), linear polarization resistance (LPR), and galvanic probes?
The Axess DCU can be used with electrical resistance (ER), linear polarization resistance (LPR), and galvanic probes, allowing users to change probe technology without changing hardware.
How does the Axess DCU (Data Collection Unit) transfer data to the Axess HHU?
The Axess DCU (Data Collection Unit) can download data to the Axess HHU via the RS-232 Serial ASCII connection.
Why is the Axess DCU capable of reading all types of electrical resistance (ER), linear polarization resistance (LPR) and galvanic probes?

The Axess DCU is capable of reading all types of electrical resistance (ER), linear polarization resistance (LPR) and galvanic probes because it is a high resolution, battery powered, corrosion monitoring instrument designed for this purpose.
Where can the Axess DCU be mounted, and what is required for mounting to these locations?
The Axess DCU can be directly mounted to site structure or Axess low and high pressure access systems using an optional mounting bracket kit.
What are the key functions of the CDAS software used with the Axess DCU (Data Collection Unit)?
The Axess DCU's software, CDAS, is used to graph metal loss trends, calculate corrosion rates, and export data in csv (comma separated value) format.
What is the part number for the battery pack used in the Axess Data Collection Unit?
The part number for the 7.2V 5Ah Lithium Battery Pack for the Axess Data Collection Unit is AXDCUHBBAT.
What is the resolution of the Axess DCU (Data Collection Unit)?
The resolution of the Axess DCU is 20 bits.
Where can the Axess DCU (Data Collection Unit) be mounted, and what is required for mounting to these locations?
The Axess DCU can be directly mounted to site structures or Axess low and high pressure access systems using an optional mounting bracket kit.
What are the communication specifications for the RS-232 Serial ASCII bus used by the Axess DCU?
The Axess DCU utilizes an RS-232 Serial ASCII bus with specifications of 9600, 8, N, 1 for communication.
Why is the Axess DCU compatible with electrical resistance (ER), linear polarization resistance (LPR), and galvanic probes?

The Axess DCU can be used with electrical resistance (ER), linear polarization resistance (LPR), and galvanic probes because it is a high resolution, battery powered, corrosion monitoring instrument capable of reading all types of these probes.
Where can the Axess DCU be mounted, and what is the part number of the kit required for mounting to these locations?
The Axess DCU can be mounted directly to site structure or Axess low and high pressure access systems using an optional mounting bracket kit (AXDCUBRKT).
What are the key functions of the CDAS software used with the Axess DCU?
The CDAS software is used to graph metal loss trends, calculate corrosion rates, and export data in csv (comma separated value) format for import into excel and other applications.
Where can the Axess DCU (Data Collection Unit) be configured?
The Axess DCU (Data Collection Unit) can be configured with the Axess HHU or on the DCU LED panel.

The Axess Data Collection Unit (AXDCUHB) weighs 1.7kg (3.8lb).
What are the dimensions of the Axess Data Collection Unit (AXDCUHB) in inches and millimeters?
The Axess Data Collection Unit (AXDCUHB) has dimensions of 6.5" x 6.5" x 4.25" (165mm x 165mm x 108mm).

AXDCUHB

meta.doc: Axess Direct Injection Fittings - Product Information (1)

messages.content: What are the key features of the Axess Direct Injection system that differentiate it from systems requiring tee fittings?

The Axess Direct Injection system allows the use of non-tee fittings while maintaining safety, reliability, and online servicing capability, including secondary isolation with a pressure retaining cover.

meta.doc: Axess Direct Injection Fittings - Product Information (1)

messages.content: What are the maximum pressure and temperature ratings of the Axess Direct Injection system?
The Axess Direct Injection system is pressure rated up to 10,000 PSI / 689 BAR and temperatures up to 204℃ / 400°F.

meta.doc: Axess Direct Injection Fittings - Product Information (1)

messages.content: What is a key design feature of the hollow plug used in the Axess Direct Injection system?
The Direct Injection system uses a special version of the hollow plug incorporating two internal one way check valves.

meta.doc: Axess Direct Injection Fittings - Product Information (1)

messages.content: What is the standard size range for drip feed tubes and quills offered by Axess?
Standard sizes for drip feed tubes and quills range between 1/4" and 3/4".

meta.doc: Axess Direct Injection Fittings - Product Information (1)

messages.content: What material is the primary packing in Axess plugs made from, and what alternative materials are available for high-temperature applications?
The primary packing in Axess plugs is made from PTFE (15% glass filled) as standard, but are available in a range of materials including metal seals for high temperature service.

meta.doc: Axess Direct Injection Fittings - Product Information (1)

messages.content: How does the quill design in parallel injection contribute to the dispersion of treatment chemicals?
Parallel injection uses a notched quill design at the center of the line which creates an artificial turbulence in the fluid flow to disperse the treatment chemical more effectively.

meta.doc: Axess Direct Injection Fittings - Product Information (1)

messages.content: What are the standard materials that Axess plugs are available in?
Axess plugs are available in 316 SS and Duplex as standard.

meta.doc: Axess Direct Injection Fittings - Product Information (1)

messages.content: What integrity management benefits are realized with the Axess Direct Injection system?
Integrity management benefits include reduced side connections that may be threaded or welded.

meta.doc: Axess Direct Injection Fittings - Product Information (1)

messages.content: Under what conditions is atomization a useful method for chemical injection?
Atomization is only useful for injection into gas filled spaces or treating gas systems.

meta.doc: Axess Direct Injection Fittings - Product Information (1)

messages.content: What are the maximum pressure and temperature ratings at which the Axess Direct Injection system can be safely serviced online?
The Axess Direct Injection system can be serviced safely online at pressures up to 6,000 PSI / 413 Bar and temperatures up to 232°C / 450°F.

meta.doc: Axess Direct Injection Fittings - Product Information (1)

messages.content: In what scenarios are Axess Direct Injection fittings particularly useful for installation or repurposing?
Axess Direct Injection fittings can repurpose existing monitoring fittings or allow installation of new injection points at critical locations where space may be restricted.

meta.doc: Axess Direct Injection Fittings - Product Information (1)

messages.content: For what specific issue related to plug threads can Axess experts provide assistance?
Axess experts can assist with material selection to reduce or eliminate galling risks in plug threads.

meta.doc: Axess Direct Injection Fittings - Product Information (1)

messages.content: How does the chemical feed disperse in perpendicular drip feeds using Axess injection systems?
For perpendicular drip feeds, an open-end tube is used, relying on the natural turbulence in the flow to disperse the chemical feed.

meta.doc: Axess Direct Injection Fittings - Product Information (1)

messages.content: What are the specifications of the 3-hole pressure retaining cover used with the Axess Direct Injection fitting?
The 3-hole pressure retaining cover for the Axess Direct Injection fitting has a 3/4" NPT center hole with a pressure gauge and bleed plug.

meta.doc: Axess Direct Injection Fittings - Product Information (1)

messages.content: Under what conditions are special plug designs required for the Axess Direct Injection system, and what calculations are they based on?
Special plug designs are available for high-velocity applications based on results from wake frequency calculations. Consult Axess for more information.

messages.content: What are the standard materials in which Axess access fittings are manufactured?
Access fittings are available in ASTM A105, ASTM A350 Gr.LF2 and Duplex steel as standard materials.

messages.content: How does the hollow plug in the Axess Direct Injection system prevent backflow during chemical injection?

The Direct Injection system uses a special version of the hollow plug incorporating two internal one way check valves, which allows chemical to be injected into the line through the center of the plug and prevents flowback of process into the injection line.

Axess access fittings are manufactured in ASTM A105, ASTM A350 Gr.LF2 and Duplex steel as standard materials. Other versions (e.g. HUB fittings) and materials are available upon request.

The Axess Direct Injection system can be used with non-tee fittings, maintaining safety, reliability, and online servicing capability, including secondary isolation with a pressure retaining cover.

Axess Direct Injection fittings are pressure rated up to 10,000 PSI / 689 BAR and temperatures up to 204℃ / 400°F.

messages.content: In what scenarios is the Axess Direct Injection system particularly useful regarding existing monitoring fittings or new injection points?
The Axess Direct Injection system can be used to repurpose existing monitoring fittings or install new injection points where space is restricted.

The Janus Access System allows insertion and retrieval of devices under pressure, enabling continuous monitoring without process shutdown.

messages.content: How do Axess HR ER probes compensate for changes in electrical resistance due to factors like temperature?

Axess HR ER probes utilize a second element, called the reference element, which is manufactured from the same material as the measurement element. The reference element is stored inside the body of the probe, where it is shielded from the process and used to auto-compensate for changes in electrical resistance due to other factors such as temperature.

meta.doc: Axess Electrical Resistance (ER) Probes - Product Information March 2025 (1)

messages.content: What are the pressure and temperature ratings of Axess ER probes?
Axess ER probes are pressure and temperature rated to 6000PSI and 260°C.

meta.doc: Axess Electrical Resistance (ER) Probes - Product Information March 2025 (1)

messages.content: What range of element thicknesses are available for cylindrical and Surface Strip Underground ER Probes?
The available element thicknesses for Underground ER Probes range from 10mil to 40mil for the Surface Strip element, and 10mil to 50mil for the cylindrical option.

meta.doc: Axess Electrical Resistance (ER) Probes - Product Information March 2025 (1)

messages.content: What options are available when configuring the part number for Axess High Pressure Retrievable ER Probes?

The part numbering system for High Pressure Retrievable ER Probes includes options for element type (Tubular/Cylindrical, Flush), element thickness (5mil, 10mil, 20mil, 40mil, 50mil), element material (Pipe Grade CS, 304 SS, 316L SS, S2205, C276, Alloy 625, Alloy 825, F51 DSS, F60 DSS, F53 SDSS, F55 SDSS), and probe body material (316/316L SS, C276, Alloy 625, Alloy 825).

meta.doc: Axess Electrical Resistance (ER) Probes - Product Information March 2025 (1)

messages.content: Where is the grounding lead installed on Axess Underground ER probes, and under what condition is this different?
The grounding lead for Underground ER probes is installed at the connector end, unless otherwise specified.

meta.doc: Axess Electrical Resistance (ER) Probes - Product Information March 2025 (1)

messages.content: Why can Axess HR ER probes be used in almost any environment?
Axess ER probes can be used in almost any environment because they operate independently of the process properties.

meta.doc: Axess Electrical Resistance (ER) Probes - Product Information March 2025 (1)

messages.content: What are the key differences between tubular element probes and flush probes in Axess ER probe configurations, and where is each best suited for monitoring?

Tubular element probes are more robust and have longer lifespans, making them ideally suited for monitoring the center of the line. Flush probes are suited for monitoring the top and bottom of the line where localized corrosion may occur because they can be installed with the element positioned in line with the pipe wall.

meta.doc: Axess Electrical Resistance (ER) Probes - Product Information March 2025 (1)

messages.content: How does incorporating Axess HR ER probes and High-Resolution instrumentation into an integrity management program benefit operators, integrity, and maintenance teams?

By incorporating Axess HR ER probes and High-Resolution instrumentation into an integrity management program, operators, integrity, and maintenance teams can achieve early, reliable detection of changes in corrosion/erosion rates, allowing them to optimize corrosion control programs, increase safety, and extend asset life.

meta.doc: Axess Electrical Resistance (ER) Probes - Product Information March 2025 (1)

messages.content: What does an Axess Underground ER probe measure when its grounding lead is left unconnected from the structure?
If the grounding lead is left unconnected from the structure, the probe monitors the direct corrosivity of the soil or environment.

meta.doc: Axess Electrical Resistance (ER) Probes - Product Information March 2025 (1)

messages.content: For Axess High Pressure Retrievable ER Probes, which element type is compatible with the 'ES' element shield?
The 'ES' element shield is only available for use with tubular/cylindrical elements in High Pressure Retrievable ER Probes.

meta.doc: Axess Electrical Resistance (ER) Probes - Product Information March 2025 (1)

messages.content: What are the temperature ratings for the surface strip and cylindrical elements of Axess Underground ER Probes?
The temperature rating for Axess Underground ER Probes is 176°F (80℃) for the surface strip element and 392°F (200℃) for the cylindrical element.

meta.doc: Axess Electrical Resistance (ER) Probes - Product Information March 2025 (1)

messages.content: How should the 'Standard' element shield be indicated in the part numbering system for Axess High Pressure Retrievable ER Probes?
The 'Standard' element shield option for Axess High Pressure Retrievable ER Probes should be left blank in the part numbering system.

meta.doc: Axess Electrical Resistance (ER) Probes - Product Information March 2025 (1)

messages.content: According to the Axess online dashboard, what parameters can be monitored using Axess ER probes?
Axess ER probes can be used to monitor metal loss, corrosion rate, and temperature, as displayed on the Axess online dashboard.

meta.doc: Axess Electrical Resistance (ER) Probes - Product Information March 2025 (1)

messages.content: How does the Axess online dashboard facilitate monitoring by exception?
The Axess online dashboard allows users to set multiple thresholds for alarms that will send email or SMS alerts, enabling monitoring by exception.

messages.content: What fitting options are available for Axess ER probes?
Axess ER probes are available with NPT, 1" inserts, and 2" HP fitting options.

meta.doc: Axess Electrical Resistance (ER) Probes - Product Information March 2025 (1)

messages.content: What are the advantages of using the cylindrical element in the Axess ERUG corrosion probe, and where is it best applied?

The cylindrical element of the Axess ERUG corrosion probe is economical and durable, and its slim profile is convenient for locations with restricted access such as concrete bridge structures and other infrastructure applications.

For whom is the Axess Innovation HIVE system designed?
HIVE is designed for Oil and Gas Operators, Asset Managers, Inspection Engineers, Corrosion Engineers, and Production Chemists.
What technology does the Axess Innovation HIVE system use to create a digital representation of assets?
HIVE uses LiDAR technology to create an accurate digital representation of assets.
What is the accuracy of point-to-point measurements in the Axess Innovation HIVE system, and at what distance is this accuracy maintained?
HIVE's built-in point-to-point measurements boast an accuracy of 2mm at 60m distance.
What functionalities does the Axess Innovation HIVE system offer for engineers regarding tagging locations and uploading reports?

The Axess Innovation HIVE system allows engineers to tag critical locations and upload essential reports, including detailed work instructions, HAZIDs, and general arrangement drawings complete with materials and specifications.
What is the function of the Axess Innovation HIVE field app regarding QR codes and report generation?
The HIVE field app allows users to scan QR codes on equipment and vials, generating comprehensive reports with automated inclusion of coupon weights and serial numbers.
What capabilities does the Axess Innovation HIVE system offer for project management of field work?
HIVE's project management features allow management of field work, from Cost, Time, and Resource (CTR) planning to final reporting.
What types of real-time data does the Axess Innovation HIVE system provide from connected sensors?

HIVE provides real-time data from connected sensors, including corrosion and erosion monitoring probes, ATP and qPCR microbial results, residual measurements, iron counts, pressure, temperature, and vibration data.
What is the function of the chemical monitoring module in the Axess Innovation HIVE system?
The chemical monitoring module in HIVE provides live visibility of the current injection regime and allows adjustments to maintain KPI compliance.
What is a distinctive feature of the Axess Innovation HIVE system regarding metal loss rates?
HIVE can generate point to point MPY metal loss rates.

For which specific industry is the Axess Innovation HIVE system tailored, and what unique capabilities does it offer?
The Axess Innovation HIVE system is tailored for the oil and gas industry, offering unique visualization and data trending capabilities.

The Axess Innovation HIVE system offers smart alerts via text message or email notifications for events or regular data reports.
What is the accuracy of the point-to-point measurements provided by the Axess Innovation HIVE system, and at what distance is this accuracy maintained?
The point-to-point measurements in the Axess Innovation HIVE system have an accuracy of 2mm at a distance of 60m.

messages.content: Why are Axess multiple disc coupons typically mounted at the top, center, and bottom of a pipe?

Multiple disc coupons are typically mounted at top, center and bottom of a pipe (inner bore diameter permitting) to allow monitoring corrosion rate across multiple fluid / gas phases within the process flow. The access fitting would normally be located at the top (12o'clock) of the pipe.

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: Where is the access fitting normally located on the pipe when using Axess ladder coupons?

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: Where is the access fitting normally located on the pipe when using Axess multiple disc coupon holders?
The access fitting would normally be located at the top (12o'clock) of the pipe when using multiple disc coupon holders.

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: What length options are available for Axess flush disc coupon holders?
Flush disc coupon holders are available with fixed length and also with adjustable length.

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: What is the formula for calculating the coupon holder length (L) for top of the line monitoring when using standard mechanical flare-weld access fitting assemblies?
The coupon holder length (L) for top of the line monitoring is calculated as L = (A + PW + WG) - 2.5".

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: How is the coupon holder length (L) calculated for flush monitoring, and what type of coupon is this formula intended for?

The coupon holder length (L) for flush monitoring is calculated as L = (A + PW + WG) - 2.815". This positions the coupon face flush to the pipe inner wall at the entry point, and is for flush disc coupons only.

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: What is the formula for calculating coupon holder length (L) for middle of the line monitoring, and when else is this formula used?

The coupon holder length (L) for middle of the line monitoring is calculated as L = (A + '/2PD + WG) - (2.5" + 1/2EL). This formula is also used for top and center of the line monitoring in the case of a multiple disc coupon holder.

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: How is the coupon holder length (L) calculated for bottom of the line monitoring, and in what other scenarios is this formula applicable?

The coupon holder length (L) for bottom of the line monitoring is calculated as L = (A + PD + WG) - (2.75" + PW + EL). This formula is also used for top, center and bottom of the line monitoring in the case of ladder and multiple disc coupon holders.

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: In the coupon holder sizing formulas, what do the variables A, PW, PD, EL, and WG represent?

A = Length of Flare-weld Access fitting body
PW = Pipe wall (wall thickness of pipe)
PD = Pipe diameter (outside diameter of pipe)
EL = Effective length of coupon (the portion of the coupon exposed to the environment, i.e. 3" coupon = 1-5", 6" coupon = 4-3/4")
WG = Weld gap (as per weld procedures, 1/16" is normal per ANSI B31.1 1973)

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: What should be done if the calculated coupon holder length is not an even '/." increment?
If the calculated coupon holder length is not an even '/." increment, it should be rounded back to the previous '/." increment.

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: What should you do if you need to calculate coupon holder lengths for applications other than standard mechanical flare-weld access fitting assemblies?
For coupon holder length calculations for applications other than standard mechanical flare-weld access fitting assemblies, contact Axess or log in to Kickstarter via the Axess website.

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: According to the formulas, what are the effective lengths (EL) for a 3" coupon and a 6" coupon?
The effective length of a 3" coupon is 1-5", while the effective length of a 6" coupon is 4-3/4".

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: What is the normal weld gap (WG) according to ANSI B31.1 1973?
The weld gap (WG) is normally 1/16" as per ANSI B31.1 1973.

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: For what coupon position and coupon holder types is the formula L = (A + PD + WG) - (2.75" + PW + EL) used?

The formula L = (A + PD + WG) - (2.75" + PW + EL) is used to position the coupon approximately '/." off the bottom of the line. It is also used for top, center, and bottom of the line monitoring when using ladder and multiple disc coupon holders.

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: What formula is used to calculate the coupon holder length for top of the line monitoring?
The formula L = (A + PW + WG) - 2.5" is used to calculate the coupon holder length for top of the line monitoring.

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: What formula is used to calculate the coupon holder length for flush monitoring, and what type of coupon is this formula intended for?
The formula L = (A + PW + WG) - 2.815" is used to calculate the coupon holder length for flush monitoring, specifically when using a flush disc coupon.

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: What formula is used to calculate coupon holder length for middle of the line monitoring, and when else is this formula used?

The formula L = (A + '/2PD + WG) - (2.5" + 1/2EL) is used to calculate the coupon holder length for middle of the line monitoring. It is also used for top and center of the line monitoring in the case of a multiple disc coupon holder.

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: What formula is used to calculate coupon holder length for bottom of the line monitoring, and in what other scenarios is this formula applicable?

The formula L = (A + PD + WG) - (2.75" + PW + EL) is used to calculate the coupon holder length for bottom of the line monitoring. It is also used for top, center and bottom of the line monitoring in the case of ladder and multiple disc coupon holders.

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: What is the formula for calculating the coupon holder length (L) for top of the line monitoring?
The formula is L = (A + PW + WG) - 2.5", where L is the coupon holder length, A is the length of the flare-weld access fitting body, PW is the pipe wall thickness, and WG is the weld gap.

meta.doc: Axess HP Coupon Holders March 2025 rev1 (1)

messages.content: When selecting an access system, how many potential leak paths do mechanical fittings have compared to hydraulic systems?
Mechanical fittings have one potential leak path, while hydraulic systems have five (four locking pins and the plug).
What techniques can be used to eliminate galling on mechanical fittings?
Positive pressure balancing techniques and the Axess ‘Saturn’ coupon holders.
Where can galling occur in hydraulic access systems?
Galling can occur with the four external locking pins on the hydraulic system.
What are the advantages of using mechanical equipment in terms of logistics and equipment selection?
All mechanical equipment available on the market is interchangeable, spares are readily available, and prices are very competitive.
Why is servicing hydraulic fittings generally a longer process than servicing mechanical systems?

Servicing hydraulic fittings is generally a longer process due to more leak path interfaces, seals to renew (6 against 2), more mechanical threads to inspect (5 against 3), and the pressurization of the hydraulic action.
What are the pressure ratings for mechanical and hydraulic tools used with access fittings?
Mechanical tools are rated to 6000psi, while hydraulic tools can be offered at 10,000psi.
What is the maximum pressure rating for both mechanical and hydraulic access fittings?
Mechanical and hydraulic access fittings can both be rated to 10’000psi and above.
What are the causes of galling in mechanical fittings?
Poor material selection and ingress of sand etc.
Which hydraulic access system design minimizes the risk of galling?
The latest 2-Piece Hydraulic access system further prevents galling from being a risk.
What integrity issues can arise from drilling out the locking pins on a hydraulic access system due to galling?
In the past, if galling occurred with the 4 external locking pins on the hydraulic system, the pins may have to be drilled out which can lead to integrity issues with the fitting and the pipeline.
When choosing an access system, what is the difference in the number of potential leak paths between mechanical fittings and hydraulic systems?
Mechanical fittings have one potential leak path, while hydraulic systems have five (four locking pins and the plug).
Besides material selection, what specific techniques or products can prevent galling in mechanical fittings?
Positive pressure balancing techniques and the Axess ‘Saturn’ coupon holders.
Which specific hydraulic access system design minimizes the risk of galling?
The latest 2-Piece Hydraulic access system.
What is the pressure rating difference between mechanical and hydraulic tools used with access fittings?
Mechanical tools are rated to 6000psi, while hydraulic tools can be offered at 10,000psi.
Why does servicing a hydraulic fitting take longer than a mechanical system?

More leak path interfaces to check/seals to renew (6 against 2), more mechanical threads to inspect (5 against 3), and the pressurization of the hydraulic action of the tool can be a much longer process.
Besides positive pressure balancing, what are the causes of galling in mechanical fittings?
Poor material selection and ingress of sand etc.
When choosing an access system, how many potential leak paths do mechanical fittings have compared to hydraulic systems, and what are the specific leak points in the hydraulic system?
Mechanical fittings have one potential leak path, while hydraulic systems have five (four locking pins and the plug).
What is the pressure rating of mechanical tools compared to hydraulic tools used with access fittings?
Mechanical tools are rated to 6000psi, while hydraulic tools can be offered at 10,000psi.

When selecting an access system, what is the difference in the number of potential leak paths between mechanical fittings and hydraulic systems, and what are the specific leak points in the hydraulic system?
The hydraulic system has 5 potential leak paths (4 locking pins and the plug), while mechanical fittings have only 1.
Why does servicing a hydraulic fitting take longer than a mechanical system, considering the number of interfaces and threads?

Servicing hydraulic fittings involves checking/renewing more leak path interfaces (6 vs 2), inspecting more mechanical threads (5 vs 3), and the pressurization of the hydraulic action can be a longer process.
When selecting an access system, how many potential leak paths do mechanical fittings have compared to hydraulic systems, and what are the specific leak points in the hydraulic system?
Mechanical fittings have one potential leak path, while hydraulic systems have five (four locking pins and the plug).
What is the difference in the number of potential leak paths between mechanical and hydraulic access fittings?
Mechanical fittings have 1 potential leak path (the seals on the plug), while hydraulic systems have 5 potential leak paths (4 locking pins and the plug).

messages.content: What pressure rating do the Axess AXHP coupon holders support, and which access systems are they designed for use with?
The Axess AXHP range of coupon holders are designed for use with AXHP access systems and allow insertion/removal in pressurized piping systems up to 10,000psi.
What is the standard material used in the manufacturing of Axess coupon holders?
Coupon holders are manufactured in 316SS material as standard.
What are the two main styles of Axess coupon holders?
The two main styles of coupon holder are 3" strip and flush disc.
What is the difference in application between strip and flush disc coupon holders?
Strip coupon holders can be used for monitoring at a pre-selected area within the pipe, while flush disc coupon holders are ideal for monitoring inline with the pipe wall.
What formula is used to calculate the coupon holder length for top of the line monitoring?
To calculate the coupon holder length for top of the line monitoring, use the formula: (A + Pw + Wg) - 2.5".
What formula is used to calculate the coupon holder length for middle of the line monitoring?
To calculate the coupon holder length for middle of the line monitoring, use the formula: (A + 1/2Pd+ Wg) - (2.5" + 1/2EI).
What formula is used to calculate the coupon holder length for bottom of the line monitoring?
To calculate the coupon holder length for bottom of the line monitoring, use the formula: (A + Pd + Wg) - (2.75" + Pw + El).
In the formulas for calculating coupon holder length, what do the variables A, Pw, Pd, El, and Wg represent?

A = Length of Access fitting body, Pw = Pipe wall (wall thickness of pipe), Pd = Pipe diameter (outside diameter of pipe), El = Effective length of coupon (the portion of the coupon exposed to the environment, i.e. 3" coupon = 1-5/8", 6" coupon = 4-3/4"), Wg = Weld gap (per weld procedures, 1/16" is normal per ANSI B31.1 1973).
When calculating coupon holder length, what should you do if the result is not an even 0.25" increment?
If the calculated length is not an even 0.25" increment, select the next shortest to the nearest 0.25".
According to ANSI B31.1 1973, what is the normal weld gap (Wg) used in the coupon holder length calculation formulas?
The weld gap (Wg) is normally 1/16" per ANSI B31.1 1973.
Besides strip and flush disc coupon holders, what other types are available for specialist monitoring in multiphase lines?
Additional coupon holder types including ladder coupons and multidisc are available for specialist monitoring within multiphase lines.
What is the maximum pressure rating for the Axess AXHP range of coupon holders?
The Axess AXHP range of coupon holders allow the insertion and removal of corrosion coupons in pressurized piping systems up to 10,000psi.
What type of analysis is conducted using corrosion coupons after they are removed from the process system?
Corrosion coupons are intrusively inserted into the process system and periodically removed to conduct weight loss and visual analysis.
What is the positioning of the coupon when using a coupon holder for top of the line monitoring?
The coupon holder positions the effective length of the coupon into the pipe vessel.
What is the positioning of the coupon when using a coupon holder for middle of the line monitoring?
The coupon holder positions '/2 of the coupon on either side of pipe centerline.
What is the positioning of the coupon when using a coupon holder for bottom of the line monitoring?
The coupon holder positions coupon approximately '/." off bottom of line.
When calculating the required length of a coupon holder, how should the length be adjusted if the calculated length is not an even 0.25" increment?
If the calculated length is not an even 0.25" increment, select the next shortest to the nearest 0.25".
According to the formulas provided for calculating coupon holder length, what is the effective length (El) of a 6" coupon?
For a 6" coupon, the effective length (El) is 4-3/4".
Which access systems are the Axess AXHP coupon holders designed to be used with?
The Axess AXHP range of coupon holders are designed for use with AXHP access systems.
What is the complete formula used to calculate the required length of a coupon holder for bottom of the line monitoring?
The formula to calculate holder length for bottom of the line monitoring is (A + Pd + Wg) - (2.75" + Pw + El).
What is the complete formula used to calculate the required length of a coupon holder for middle of the line monitoring?
The formula to calculate holder length for middle of the line monitoring is (A + 1/2Pd+ Wg) - (2.5" + 1/2EI).
What corrosion rate (mpy) values are provided in the table?
The table provides corrosion rates (mpy) for values of 0.1, 2, 4, 5, 10, 20, and 25.

messages.content: What type of corrosion monitoring does the Axess Horizon access fitting provide, and what advantages does it offer?
The Axess Horizon access fitting provides bottom of the line corrosion monitoring with the safety and operational advantages of a side of the line access fitting.
How is the Axess Horizon access fitting designed for installation and hot-tapping?

The Horizon fitting is supplied with one end contoured to the size of the pipe it is to be installed onto and is partially bored through from the opposite end so it can be hot-tapped following installation.
What happens to the weld metal backing and root during the hot-tapping process of an Axess Horizon access fitting, and what type of weld is achieved?
The weld metal backing and root are removed during the hot tapping process leaving a full penetration weld.
What steps are taken after hot-tapping an Axess Horizon access fitting to prepare for monitoring device installation?
After hot-tapping, the service valve is closed, the hot-tap tool pressure is bled down and removed, and a retrieval tool can be used to install the monitoring device.
How can the Axess Horizon access fitting be sealed if the monitoring device is not immediately installed?
In instances where the monitoring device is to be installed at a later date the access fitting can be sealed with a solid plug and secondary pressure retaining cover until required.
Explain how the design of the Axess Horizon access fitting ensures a full penetration weld after hot-tapping.

The Horizon fitting is partially bored through from the opposite end so it can be hot-tapped following installation. This design provides a 'metal backed' root which is then removed post- welding during hot-tapping to provide a full penetration weld.
Why is it important to follow site-specific procedures when welding the Axess Horizon access fitting onto a pipe?
Welding should be carried out in accordance with site specific procedures.
What type of corrosion monitoring is the Axess Horizon access fitting designed to provide?
The Axess Horizon access fitting is designed to provide bottom of the line corrosion monitoring.
How is the Axess Horizon access fitting supplied to facilitate installation and hot-tapping?

The Horizon fitting is supplied with one end contoured to the size of pipe it is to be installed onto and is partially bored through from the opposite end so it can be hot-tapped following installation.
What is the procedure for hot-tapping the Axess Horizon fitting after it has been welded to the pipe?
After welding the Axess Horizon fitting to the pipe, the end profile nearest the pipe is hot-tapped using an Axess supplied hot-tap tool and temporary service valve.
What steps are taken immediately after hot-tapping the Axess Horizon fitting to prepare for installation of a monitoring device?
Following hot tapping, the service valve is closed, the hot-tap tool pressure is bled down and removed, and a retrieval tool is used to install the monitoring device.
How is the Axess Horizon access fitting supplied to facilitate installation onto a pipe?
The Horizon fitting is supplied with one end contoured to the size of pipe it is to be installed onto and is partially bored through from the opposite end.
What type of corrosion monitoring is the Axess Horizon access fitting designed to provide, and what are its key advantages?
The Axess Horizon access fitting is designed to provide bottom of the line corrosion monitoring with the safety and operational advantages of a side of the line access fitting.
What is the immediate next step after welding the Axess Horizon fitting to the pipe?
After welding the Axess Horizon fitting to the pipe, it can be hot-tapped using an Axess supplied hot-tap tool and temporary service valve.
What steps are taken immediately following the hot-tapping of the Axess Horizon fitting?
After hot-tapping the Axess Horizon fitting, the service valve is closed, the hot-tap tool pressure is bled down and removed, and a retrieval tool can then be used to install the monitoring device.
What components are used to seal the Axess Horizon access fitting if the monitoring device is not installed immediately?
If the monitoring device is not immediately installed, the Axess Horizon access fitting can be sealed with a solid plug and secondary pressure retaining cover until required.
How is the Axess Horizon fitting prepared for installation and hot-tapping?

The Horizon fitting is supplied with one end contoured to the size of pipe it is to be installed onto and is partially bored through from the opposite end so it can be hot-tapped following installation.
What happens to the weld metal backing and root during the hot-tapping process of the Axess Horizon fitting, and what type of weld is achieved?
The weld metal backing and root are removed during the hot tapping process leaving a full penetration weld.
What specific guidelines should be followed when welding the Axess Horizon access fitting onto a pipe, and why is this important?
Welding should be carried out in accordance with site specific procedures.
Why is the Axess Horizon access fitting suitable for locating the ER probe element in the water phase?
The Horizon fitting is designed to provide bottom of the line corrosion monitoring, which means the ER probe element is located in the water phase.
How is the Axess Horizon access fitting supplied to facilitate installation onto a pipe and hot-tapping?
The Horizon fitting is supplied with one end contoured to the size of pipe it is to be installed onto and is partially bored through from the opposite end.
What is the next step after the Axess Horizon fitting has been welded to the pipe?
After welding the Axess Horizon fitting to the pipe, the end profile nearest the pipe can then be hot-tapped using an Axess supplied hot-tap tool and accompanying temporary service valve.
How is the Axess Horizon fitting supplied to facilitate installation onto a pipe?
The Horizon fitting is supplied with one end contoured to the size of the pipe it is to be installed onto and is partially bored through from the opposite end.
What is the issue date of the Horizon Access Fittings document?
The Horizon Access Fittings document was issued on 04/30/2024.
For which clients are the Horizon Access Fittings intended?
Worley / Aramco / AFIC
Which product won Axess an innovation of the year award at the AMPP 2023 conference and exhibition?
Axess was awarded an innovation of the year award for the Janus Guard product.
What material is used for the Horizon access fitting?
The Horizon access fitting material is A105/A350 LF2.
What is the cost and lead time for 300 Axess® Horizon® 2" HP Flareweld 16" Run, Access Fitting Assemblies?
The cost for 300 Axess® Horizon® 2" HP Flareweld 16" Run, Access Fitting Assemblies is $420,000 and the lead time is 12 weeks.
What is the cost and lead time for 300 Axess ® 2" HP Janus Ring Joint, ANSI 1500# Access Fitting Assemblies?
The cost for 300 Axess ® 2" HP Janus Ring Joint, ANSI 1500# Access Fitting Assemblies is $2,749,905 and the lead time is 28 weeks.
What design feature enhances end user confidence in the Janus access fitting?
The Janus access fitting is designed to enhance end user confidence by adding a secondary radial sealing surface to the access fitting.
How does the Horizon fitting improve safety for 12 o'clock monitoring?
The Horizon fitting reduces the risk of working at heights, manual handling, and all the human factoring for 12 o'clock monitoring.
How does the Horizon access fitting affect pigging operations?
The Horizon access fitting reduces concerns during pigging operations when flush pitch and adjust devices are installed.
What does drawing ADD23091201_Rav depict?
The drawing ADD23091201_Rav shows the GA - HORIZON SIDE ENTRY BOL ACCESS FITTING, WITH ANGLED FLUSH DISC HOLDER.
What does drawing GAD24041801 depict?
The drawing GAD24041801 shows the TITCORROSION MONITORING AND SAMPLING TRAP SYSTEM VS HORIZON ACCESS SYSTEM.
What is the description of the part number 2PRCJA?
The 2PRCJA is a 2 HOLE JANUS PRESSURE RETAINING COVER IN A350-LF2 CARBON STEEL WITH VITON O-RINGS, PRESSURE INDICATOR AND BLEED PORT.
What is the description of the part number AX2HPJA-HZ12-NT-A4?
The AX2HPJA-HZ12-NT-A4 is a 2" HORIZON JANUS ACCESS FITTING FOR 12" NB PIPE, IN A10SN CARBON STEEL.
What problem was Axess challenged to solve by Aramco engineers?

Axess was approached by Aramco engineers to design a system to satisfy an issue which exists throughout Aramco facilities both onshore and onshore, upstream, and downstream - access to the bottom 10-20% of the pipe without access to the 6 o'clock position for retrieval equipment.
How much did Axess reduce a project cost on access fittings alone by offering A105/LF2 Horizon fittings?
By offering A105/LF2 Horizon fittings in place of 1500# RJ flanged fitting in 825, a project cost on access fittings alone was reduced by 85%.
For what applications does Axess recommend the Janus fitting?
Axess recommends the Janus™ fitting for all new applications.
To which fitting designs does the Janus™ access fitting design apply?
The Janus™ access fitting design applies to mechanical RC, ACME, Horizon, and Hydraulic fitting designs.
Why does the Horizon access system replace T trap assemblies?

The Horizon access system replaces T trap assemblies because they are an integrity and piping engineers concern and are unrepresentative of the process conditions. Aramco no longer digs pits for access, and there are usual space constraints offshore.
What is the description of the part number CCFD-HZ-G10180-B-A?
The part number CCFD-HZ-G10180-B-A describes a retrievable flush disc horizontal coupon in 1018 carbon steel.
What is the description of the part number HPHZCH-12-4.25?
The part number HPHZCH-12-4.25 describes a retrievable flush disc coupon holder for 12" Horizon access fitting, with a 4.25" order length.
What are the benefits of using Horizon fittings in terms of device length and stock management?
Using Horizon fittings means device lengths will be no longer than 8", leading to shorter and lighter retrievers and an easily managed stock inventory of replacement probes and coupon holders.
What are the material and features of the 2 Hole Janus Pressure Retaining Cover (part number 2PRCJA)?
The 2 Hole Janus Pressure Retaining Cover (part number 2PRCJA) is made of A350-LF2 carbon steel with Viton O-rings and includes a pressure indicator and bleed port.
What materials are used in the solid plug?
The solid plug is made of 316L SS with PTFE primary packing and a Viton O-ring.
With whom is Axess collaborating to develop the Janus access fittings and retrievers as a standard best practice?
Axess is working with several major operators, AMPP, and the Energy Institute to develop the Janus™ access fittings and retrievers as a standard best practice.
What materials were used for the Horizon fittings that replaced the 1500# RJ flanged fitting?
A105/LF2 Horizon fittings were offered in place of 1500# RJ flanged fitting in 825.
According to drawing GAD24041801, what materials are used for the Horizon access fitting, the inverted T-section, and the process line?
The Horizon access fitting material is A105/A350 LF2, the inverted T-section material is Alloy 825, and the process line material is API 5L GR. X65.
What is the primary function of the Janus guard product in the context of corrosion monitoring and chemical injection systems?
The Janus guard product is designed to make online retrieval safer by reducing the risks associated with intrusive internal monitoring and chemical injection systems.
According to the document, why are incidents more likely to occur on fittings at the 6 o'clock position?
Incidents often occur at the 6 o'clock position due to the fittings acting as traps for debris and gravity's influence.
What is the maximum device length when using Horizon fittings?
By using Horizon fittings, device lengths will be no longer than 8".
What are the materials used for the primary packing and O-ring in the solid plug?
The solid plug has a PTFE primary packing and a Viton O-ring.
What is the order length of the AX2HPJA-HZ12-NT-A4 access fitting?
The 2" Horizon Janus access fitting for 12" NB pipe, in A10SN carbon steel has an order length of 4.25".
According to drawing GAD24041801, what is the material of the Horizon access fitting?
The Horizon access fitting material is A105/A350 LF2.
According to drawing GAD24041801, what material is used for the inverted T-section in the example trap system?
The inverted T-section material is Alloy 825.
According to drawing GAD24041801, what material is used for the process line in the example trap system?
The process line material is API 5L GR. X65.
How does the Janus guard prevent incidents during retrieval?
The Janus guard prevents retrievers from pistoning due sudden pressure equalization after thread disengagement of the plug in the fitting.
Who is Axess collaborating with to develop the Janus access fittings and retrievers as a standard best practice?
Axess is working with several major operators as well as AMPP and the Energy Institute.
How much did Axess reduce a project cost on access fittings alone by offering A105/LF2 Horizon fittings in place of 1500# RJ flanged fitting in 825?
By offering A105/LF2 Horizon fittings in place of 1500# RJ flanged fitting in 825, Axess reduced a project cost on access fittings alone by 85%.

The Horizon Access Fittings are for clients Worley / Aramco / AFIC.
